Silver spark was a poison sometimes used by holy slayer assassins of the Soft Whisper in Zakhara.

description.paras: This poison was a radiant vapor. Rumor stated that is was derived from distilled moonlight and bottled passion. It possessed a rich and musky aroma.

uses.paras: Victims could not resist breathing deeply of this perfumed poison once a holy slayer offered it. Once inhaled, intense pain wracked the victim's body for several intense minutes.

Rob was a farmer of the town of Ghars in Cormyr in the mid–14th century DR.

relations.paras: He was drinking buddies with Bortas and Will at the Swamp Rat tavern.

personality.paras: He smoked a pipe and seemed to say little except to agree with Will.

history.paras:
On Eleasias 16 in the Year of the Shield, 1367 DR, when Farmer Bortas and his wife came to the Swamp Rat reporting they'd seen the bandit chieftain Fastred, Rob and Will joined his posse of fellow farmers and returned to the scene, but the ghost had vanished and they didn't dare venture into the Vast Swamp.

Later that year, on Eleint 17, Jasper went to the Swamp Rat tavern and met Bortas, Rob, and Will. He bought them Shadowdark ale and asked about the ghost sighting, after it was discovered to be Dovo in disguise, who was found dead.

Two nights later, on Eleint 19, Bortas, Rob, and Will came out of the Swamp Rat and saw Jasper and a group of townsfolk escorted by the Purple Dragons to Benelaius's house for the investigation into Dovo's murder.

description.paras: These rings often were simple polished golden bands that flickered with fait magical glimmer.

powers.paras:
Rings of dodging possessed several enchantments. They increased the wearer's defense by the way of agility, increased their reflexes and dexterity, and made them move faster in the heat of battle.

Some versions of these rings had more limited scope. Only able to be activated three times per day, these rings only affected one opponent, making the wearer more nimble in combat against that creature, while other opponents remained unaffected. Additionally, this version of rings of dodging gave the wearer enhance ability to doge and resist magical spells.

history.paras:
In the 14th century DR, these rings were primarily found in the the Dalelands, where most guilds often possessed one.

In 1369 DR, a ring of dodging could be found in the possession of the Cult of the Dragon, in the Elven Catacombs of Myth Drannor, among other looted magic items.

Anastes was the paramount of the storm giant aerie of Lake Woe mountain in 1369 DR.

description.paras: Anastes had pale violet skin and blue-black hair that was very long and unkempt. He was clean-shaven and typically wore a simple tunic with a large amount of silver jewelry. His eyes were silver-colored.

personality.paras:
Like most giants of Lake Woe mountain, Anastes was dour and melancholy, so much so that the weather around him was affected.

Anastes believed strongly in predestination. He acted out of duty, because he believed he did not have any true choice in any matter.

possessions.paras: Ramos bore a sword in battle that was twenty-feet long.

history.paras:
By 1369 DR, Anastes, and five other storm giants were summoned magically by Lanaxis to defend him when he needed to rest during his kidnapping of Queen Brianna and her son Kaedlaw. They heeded his call.

Anastes spoke at length with Brianna while she was nursing the child. She tried to convince him that Lanaxis was evil, but Anastes claimed that there was nothing he could do. She even showed him her son's face, which was hideously ugly, as proof that his supposed new emperor was a monster. Anastes still did not try to stop Lanaxis, but he did try as hard as he could to see that Brianna and her baby were safe and well-fed. He ordered each of the other giants to find and cook her food.

Later, while her food was still being prepared, Tavis Burdun and armies of giant-kin attacked. Anastes quickly set up a battle plan: He sent Nikol and Ramos to deal with the verbeegs, Sebastion and Patma to face the firbolgs, and Eusebius to take on the fomorians, while he himself defended the queen, her child, and Lanaxis.

During the battle, Sebastion and Patma were each slain, and the firbolgs then attacked Anastes. The fomorians, however, abandoned the field, allowing Eusebius to flank the firbolgs and assist his paramount. Anastes was struck in the stomach by the axe of Raeyadfourne, the leader of the firbolgs, but then Anastes slew him in a single swing of his massive sword. Anastes and Eusebius then managed to kill all of the remaining firbolgs except for Galgadayle and Tavis, but Eusebius also fell. Galgadayle and Tavis severely wounded Anastes, but Anastes grabbed Galgadayle around the throat to kill him. Tavis called for an end of hostilities, and the giant, seeing all of the bloodshed on both sides and that Lanaxis had escaped with the queen and her son, agreed.

organization.paras: The composition of the city guard as of 1367 DR[note 1] was 10,000 infantry, 1,000 mercenary cavalry, and a navy of 30 ships.

activities.paras: All members of the cavalry were skilled desert riders from the High Desert. The navy patrolled the Pearl Banks to protect Jumlat's investment in the area. Jumlat also hired 10–30 additional ships crewed by corsairs and privateers to harass their rival Gana.

Prince Nishan Rhindaun was the father of Queen Cyriana III of Tethyr.

relationships.paras:
Nishan was a grandson of Zaranda Star, the famous adventuress and first queen of the Rhindaun Dynasty, through his mother Queen Sybille II. His older sister, Zaranda II, was also queen of Tethyr after the death of their mother.

Nishan's daughter, Cyriana became queen of Tethyr after the death of his sister.

pages.blurb: dancing hart

description.paras: It was carved in the shape of a deer that held a cup in its antlers.

powers.paras: Certain old records of arcane matters stated that the cup component should be filled with the blood of one's foe in order to activate the power of the dancing hart. However, its actual powers were lost to history.

history.paras: As one of the Wo-ha Ui-jung, the dancing hart's powers had most likely at one stage influenced the history of Koryo. However, it was later lost. It was speculated to lie among the treasures of Toranu Gang-po, a fortress whose location was also lost by the mid–14th century DR.

The Ghost Leopard province was found in the northwest region of the Land of the Yak-Men in 1367 DR.[note 1]

geography.paras: This province of the Yikarian Empire was dominated by the World Pillar Mountains on its eastern side and foothills and rugged terrain along the River Ruin in the west and north.

inhabitants.paras: Aside from the yak-folk who controlled the region, the Ghost Leopard province was home to a large population of marrash whose eyries were scattered throughout the mountain peaks. These dangerous creatures were close allies with the yak-folk and served as aerial scouts for the area.

lists: River Ruin

pages.blurb: West Harbor was a small village near the southern end of the Mere of Dead Men along the Sword Coast.

geography.paras: West Harbor is located in Mere of Dead Men, south of Highcliff. Near the village is the portal of Illefarn ruins. The swamp also made West Harbor's farmland incredibly fertile and more than enough crops were grown to sustain the village.

inhabitants.paras: Due to its swampy terrain and annual harvest festival where the inhabitants compete against each other to win prizes in tests of skill, the villagers of West Harbor (referred to as "Harbormen") were renowned in the lands surrounding them for their natural toughness. This put them in high demand for positions as guards and military service. In addition, they tended their fields with care, since most worshiped Chauntea. However, they were a shy people.

history.paras:
Unfortunately, West Harbor has been destroyed twice, both times in recent memory. Once, when the King of Shadows first attacked Neverwinter and again several decades later when it was revisited by Ammon Jerro.

In its time, West Harbor has produced several notable people, including Marshal Cormick of the Neverwinter City Watch and Lorne Starling. Most notable of all however, was the adventurer who eventually defeated the King of Shadows, the Kalach-Cha.

rumors and legends.paras: It was here where the battle against the King of Shadows was fought. The remnant was a shadowy portion of the ground at the center of the village where Ammon Jerro clashed the Sword of Gith against the King of Shadows. Also, it was here where the Kalach-Cha grew up.

description.paras: Faldis's Defender was a stout majestic shield made of platinum.

powers.paras: Faldis's Defender was enchanted to give its wearer courage even if they possessed none prior to donning the shield. Additionally, the magic shield increased the user's armor, defense, and initiative.

history.paras: Faldis's Defender accompanied its owner, Faldis throughout his career, leading the elf to the hero status and to being buried with honors inside the Deep Halls of Dwarven Dungeons. Before his demise, Faldis wrote a confession in his diary and hid the shield inside the secret room inside his crypt. This was where the shield remained until 1369 DR.

Fahren was a Netherese arcanist who developed spells that affected the sight of others.

description.paras: The inventor was highly-respected and was said to be a true "master of magic". He educated both mages and rogues in the Art.

relationships.paras: Fahren had a good relationship with both types of his students. However, the thieves he taught used his spells to rob others.

history.paras: Fahren was born in 2357 NY (−1502 DR). He was credited with the invention of two spells: darkness, 15' radius and glitterdust. Fahren died very young at the age of 40 in 2397 NY (−1462 DR), making him one of the shortest-lived arcanists of the era, along with Efteran.

rumors & legends.paras: It was rumored that one of his rogue students used glitterdust to rob a rival arcanist. This in turn led to Fahren's death when the rival took it out on him by destroying Fahren with a sphere of annihilation.

description.paras: Amulets of Corellon were small silver crescents on a blue string.

powers.paras: These crescent amulets were imbued with divine magics that allowed its wearer to cast protection from evil on themselves and three allies. These items could be used exclusively by clerics of Corellon.

lists: Halbenet Soladonel: a moon elf cleric of Corellon Larethian who worked with other warriors of Waterdeep, performing missions on behalf of Laeral Silverhand in the late 15th century DR.

The Beast Lord was the local name given to an alhoon mage that dwelled within the ruined mines of Dekanter, carried on horrific arcane experiments, and waged a war against mostly unknown forces of the Underdark, for hundreds of years as of the 15th century DR.

personality.paras: The former mind flayer known as the Beast Lord was driven mad by memories of the gith taken from the elder brain at its spawning pool within ruined Dekanter. It displayed obsessive, secretive, and maniacal behavior, seemingly wanting to conquer the the North and parts of the Deepearth.

activities.paras:
Within the mind flayer's lair in the ruins of Dekanter, within the Greypeak Mountains of the Savage Frontier, the Beast Lord used various athanors to create twisted monsters, such as: bulettes, stegocentipedes, peryton, beholders, mongrelmen. and perhaps its most famously, the unique Dekanter goblins. It was believed that the Beast Lord's experiments in biological transmutation were an attempt to recreate the Gith species from the goblins of Dekanter, and in some twisted way please its former elder brain. By recreating the Gith the Beast Lord sought to achieve commencement, and join its consciousness to that of its former parent elder brain.

While pursuing its aberrant experiments and carrying out this twisted plan, the Beast Lord waged a war against some unknown forces within the Underdark, and more specifically the Deepearth. It was known to be in open war with the living illithid colony of Llacerelly, though it was entirely possible other colonies were involved as well.

relationships.paras:
The Beast Lord shared his lair with the goblins of Dekanter led by Lord High Chief Ghistpok. To aid the illithid in his war in the North, the Beast Lord commanded 500 of Ghistpok's goblins along with 50 gargoyle minions.

After having formed an alliance with the Zhentarim, the Beast Lord fought the forces of the drow and the Harpers. Within the Dungeon of the Hark, the mind flayer had a roper ally known as Xuchallit.

history.paras:
In Ches of the Year of the Prince, 1357 DR, rumors spread about the rise of a Beast Lord in the North who used magic to create monstrous creatures, such as gorgimera and owlbears. Around the following year, the Black Network delivered dead bodies to the Beast Lord to encourage the illithid to not attack their caravans.

In the Year of Maidens, 1361 DR, the Beast Lord recovered the one of the Nether Scrolls of ancient Netheril, somehow connected the artifact to his great brass athanor, and magnified its experimental transformations in both their multitude and depravity. It began to create new monstrosities, Dekanter goblins merged with the awakened mantises from the nearby Weathercote Wood. Within six years, the situation grew beyond the control of the Zhent Lord Amarandaris of Parnast, and he was forced to reroute the trail leading past the mines and pull Zhentarim forces away from the region.

Growing concerned about the Beast Lord's increasing power while in possession of the Nether Scroll the otherworldly being known as Lady Wyndyfarh, dispatched a lost goblin from the mines named Sheemzher to enlist the aid of good folks from the nearby towns. Sheemzher joined with the honest mage named Druhallen, his bodyguard companion Rozt'a, and her foster son Tiep to steal the Nether Scroll away from the Beast Lord. The Beast Lord's powerful magic proved too much for the meager travelers, but an assault by mind flayers from Llacerelly was opportunity enough for the surface-dwellers to recover the scroll and flee from Dekanter.

The ancient alhoon survived the assault, and remained within Dekanter for a number of years. By the Year of Lightning Storms, 1374 DR, the Beast Lord was continuing his search for ancient Netherese treasure along with his hordes of Dekanter goblins, many of which had spread far and wide in the Greypeak Mountains beyond his lair. Rumors about the Beast Lord's activities within the mountains persisted for over the following century and beyond.

rumors and legends.paras: During the reign of the Beast Lord, both the Harpers and the Lords' Alliance posted a reward of 500 gold pieces for any information concerning its heinous activities.

pages.blurb: Erik the Fin

description.paras: Erik was a shifty-looking element often seen pacing along Daggerford's docks.

history.paras:
In 1372 DR, Erik the Fin became involved in a malicious plot to abduct Delfen Ondabarl's dear friend. Said friend was shoved inside a chest and as Erik was loading it up onto his boat he dropped it into Delimbiyr River. Fearful of his benefactor and unable to leave the city due to a lockdown, Erik asked for help to retrieve his precious cargo with unknown contents. The chest washed out somewhere along the river banks. Unfortunately for the man, the person who answered his call for aid was the Hero of Daggerford.

Erik the Fin was hired by Mogdor to track down and capture the imp name Sujit. The criminal captured the hellish creature and stuck him in the chest. Eventually, the box was recovered by the Hero of Daggerford, but instead of being returned to Erik, the adventurer reunited Sujit with his friend and master Delfen Ondabarl of Sorceller's Encapsulate in Daggerford. What was delivered to Erik, however was a chest with a deadly surprise intended for Mogdor.

As the chest was unlocked, a powerful demilich Extallimix emerged from his slumber, Mogdor was seeming killed by the angry undead, as Erik the Fin fled for his life in sight of his employer's violent death.

Tufala bint Maneira was a half-elven rawun inhabiting the High Desert of Zakhara around 1367 DR[note 1] who related the history of her desert tribe through her stories and music.

description.paras: Tufala has chestnut-colored hair.

activites.paras: Tufala inherited her duties as the tribal storyteller and historian from her elven mother. She took her responsibilities seriously. She was well-informed about current rumors of the High Desert.

possessions.paras: Tufala wore leather armor and carried an enchanted jambiya and a normal cutlass. She played her pipes of sounding to help relate her stories.

pages.blurb: guild

guild membership.paras: Guild membership was generally open to those who possessed some skill in the guild's primary activity. In many cases, interested persons needed only to approach the guild and apply for membership. Occasionally, additional entry requirements such as belonging to a certain race were imposed. Some guilds, such as thieves guilds, were secret societies so even learning of the existence of these guilds could be difficult. Guilds normally required an entry fee as well as periodic fees to remain in good standing. Benefits of membership in a guild could include access to the guildhall, discounts on trade materials and possibly financial support in the form of loans.

adventurers guilds.paras:
In some cities, those who hunted monsters and delved in dungeons banded together to form adventurers guilds. These guilds functioned as employment agencies for members and offered additional services, such as search parties for missing adventuring groups.

Notable adventurer guilds:
lists: Order of Delvers

arcane guilds.paras:
Guilds made up primarily of arcane spellcasters were known as arcane guilds. Membership was generally limited to mages, sorcerers, and other users of arcane magic such as bards.

Notable arcane guilds:
lists: Arcane Brotherhood
Brotherhood of the Cloak
High House of Magic
Watchful Order of Magists and Protectors

criminal guilds.paras:
These guilds were made up of those operating outside the law. They tended to be highly secretive and could be difficult to join. They offered benefits such as training, employment, and help selling stolen goods.

Notable criminal guilds:
lists: Night Masks
Shadow Thieves
Shadowmasters of Telflamm

laborers guilds.paras:
These guilds were associations of low-skilled manual laborers. Not surprisingly, laborers guilds were unpopular with merchants and others who depended on low-paid workers.

The Cellarers' & Plumbers' Guild of Waterdeep was an example of a laborer build in the Realms.

mercantile guilds.paras:
The most common form of guilds, mercantile guilds were associations of merchants engaged in trading a particular good. Large mercantile guilds could be extremely powerful and could control trade in their area of specialization. Some mercantile guilds required practitioners of a trade to join before setting up shop within their area. Mercantile guilds offered benefits such as protection from criminals and excessive governmental taxation and might even loan money to members.

Notable mercantile guilds:
lists: Merchant's League
Silent Sail

performers guilds.paras: Performers guilds were made up of bards, actors and others who performed for a living. These guilds promoted entertainment events and would match members with complementary talents to form troupes.

scholastic guilds.paras: Guilds whose members were primarily engaged in scholarly pursuits were known as scholastic guilds. Membership was usually composed of sages and mages. Many guilds had libraries and extremely large guilds founded colleges. Some arcane guilds could be considered scholastic guilds and vice versa.

Vevette Blackwater (pronounced: /vɛˈvɛt/ veh-VET) was a high-ranking member of Manshoon's Zhentarim in Waterdeep during the early 1490s DR.

activities.paras: Vevette resided inside Kolat Tower with her master Manshoon.

history.paras: In 1492 DR,[note 1] if Manshoon managed to obtain the Stone of Golorr, after the Xanathar's Thieves' Guild and some adventurers discovered the Stone's hiding place devised by the dragonborn butcher Thrakkus, Vevette was instructed to deliver the Stone to the fellow Zhent Agorn Fuoco and she managed to deliver it during a performance at the Trades Ward theater called the Brizzenbright.

relationship.paras: Vevette was one of the lieutenants of Manshoon.

An elven Everskan tomb guardian.

Evereskan Tomb Guardian

Class Statistics




								3e
							




3rd Edition Statistics

Magic Use

Arcane magic

Requirements

Race

List of known evereskan Tomb Guardians

Evereskan tomb guardians were an order of elven warriors and spellcasters that watched over and protected the final resting places of Evereska's most revered ancestors.

admission.paras: Those who sought to become tomb guardians had to have some degree of arcane spellcasting capability, combat ability, and skills in tracking, stealth, and alertness. They were typically sorcerers who trained as a ranger or rogue.

activities.paras:
To the elves of Evereska, nothing was more sacred than the remains of their deceased forebears and great heroes, interred within countless tombs scattered around their ancestral home in the Western Heartlands. Tomb guardians took a special oaths to protect these sacred places and hunt down, punish, and even kill any scavengers or tomb robbers that would defile their sacred crypts—even if they had to chase them to the ends of the world.

Tombs east of Evereska, on the border of the Anauroch desert, were frequently patrolled by tomb guardians, as they were a regular target of human and humanoid tomb robbers. Some tombs belonged to hated long-dead elven families, but nonetheless the tomb guardians upheld their oaths to protect these burial places.

abilities.paras:
Tomb guardian continued to hone their arcane spellcasting abilities an cultivated a wide range of skills related to their duty. They did not travel far from their home in the Western Heartlands to continue their studies.

Novice guardians knew they had a sacred duty to watch over the long-deceased citizens of Evereska. Thanks to this nature of their mission, a beginner tomb guardian had an edge when it came to stalking their quarry within the borders of Evereska, whether by tracking, gaining information, or hunting them down. If inside a tomb itself, they became ever more fierce warriors.

More experienced tomb guardian's retained their edge in tracking and pursuing tomb robbers beyond Evereska's tombs and outside of the city's borders. As they honed their skills and combat prowess, they excelled at dodging attacks.

Veteran tomb guardians could track any creature whilst moving at full speed across land. A supremely skilled tomb guardian could make themself the dedicated guardian of a certain area. After ten minutes or so of dedicated focus, they attuned themself their surroundings and became much more alert and stealthy within 100 ft  (30 m) of their point of focus.

relationships.paras: At times, the Tomb Guardians were known to work alongside the justices of weald and woe, the special agents of Eldreth Veluuthra.

history.paras:
At some point, contingent of Tomb Guardians led an unsuccessful mission to explore the depths of Shaalkar Manor believed to be a remnant of House Vyshaan, but were forced to flee after losing a handful of their members.

In the Year of the Unstrung Harp, 1371 DR, a contingent of Evereskan Tomb Guardians under the leadership of Galaeron Nihmedu apprehended a group of Vaasans led by the enigmatic Melegaunt Tanthul underneath the Desert Border South region of Anauroch. During their encounter, magic cast by Galaeron reacted with shadow magic cast by Melegaunt and a hole in the Sharn Wall and "inadvertently" let the phaerimm loose on Faerûn.

lists: Galaeron Nihmedu, a tomb guardian and sorcerer of Evereska.
Kiinyon Colbathin, Tomb Master

pages.blurb: Adarbrent (pronounced: /ɑːˈdɑːrbrɛnt/ ah-DAR-brent) was a noble family that lived in Waterdeep during the 14th century DR. They were among the leading shipping clans as of 1372 DR, possessing the city's third-largest fleet and holding strong ties with the Master Mariners' Guild.

organization.paras:
As of 1368 DR, the patriarch of the Adarbrent family was Lord Royus Adarbrent, with no acting consort. Alroy Adarbrent was Royus' eldest son and designated heir. In 1372 DR there were eighty-six living members of the Adarbrent noble family. [note 1]

The majority of human family members were of Chondathan ethnicity.

activities.paras: The family were founding members of Horizon Armada, a league of ship-owners among the city's nobility that managed the sea lanes, coordinated their various fleets, and commissioned maritime maps.

base of operations.paras: The family owned a villa in the North Ward, on the east side of Shield Street between Julthoon Street and Manycats Alley.

history.paras:
The family traveled from Cormyr to Waterdeep in 1310 DR to seek further wealth and prosperity with the Adarbrent Shipping Company. Finding immediate success, they quickly improved their station in life, joining Waterdeep's nobility in 1317 DR.

Lady Adarbrent gave birth to her third son, Ellis in 1344 DR. Some time later she passed away. Lord Royus never stopped mourning her death.

In the spring of 1372 DR, the impulsive and adventurous Syllia eloped to New Waterdeep with her lover, and fellow Harper, Farid al-Nisr. Lord Royus and her brothers didn't respond well to the news.

While some of Royus's brothers in House Adarbrent became rich from the cross-sea trade with New Waterdeep on the continent of Maztica, the Deepwater War left the family financially unsure. Following these developments, Lord Royus began to explore borrowing gold, at a very low interest rate, from Fahd yn Sarsor al-Nisr, Syllia's father-in-law. Unbeknownst to anyone in House Adarbrent, the senior Al-Nisr was Yrshelem within the Rundeen, who sought to takeover the financial holdings of the Waterdhavian family.

lists: Lord Royus Adarbrent: The family's patriarch
Alroy Adarbrent: A physically weak man with a keen mind for sailing and navigation
Ellis Adarbrent: Third-born son of Royus and Lady Adarbrent
Syllia Adarbrent: Captain of the Hippocampus and agent of the Harpers
Arilosa Adarbrent.
Lady Adarbrent
Dorgar Adarbrent

Judgment of Abd Hikmat

The Judgment of Abd Hikmat was an item that could be found in Zakhara, the Land of Fate.

description.paras: This item was a simple scroll with nonmagical script.

powers.paras: This scroll was the judgment of Abd Hikmat, a long-dead qadi whose name literally meant "slave of wisdom," concerning ownership rights to the pearl banks of Jumlat and Gana. Abd Hikmat ruled that Jumlat broke the Law and awarded more of the banks to Gana.

description.paras: Tharlgarl was a huge man who resembled a bear who prided himself for his great white mustaches that hung below his chin. His nickname – "Steelfists," came from the man's habit of wearing a heavy set of gold-ornamented pompous plate mail, even in Arrabarran sweltering hot and humid climate.

relationships.paras: Tharlgarl "Steelfists" Darowdryn could often be seen accompanying and guarding his aunt Ariskrit Darowdryn, the aging matriarch of House Darowdryn.

history.paras: On Tarsakh 10 of the Year of Rogue Dragons, 1373 DR, Ariskrit and Tharlgarl Steelfists attended Emriana Matrell's grand celebration of becoming an adult, an Arrabarran tradition for a woman's 16th birthday. During the celebration, Tharlgarl and Ariskrit witnessed an assassination attempt on Hetta Matrell's life orchestrated by the cabal of Talriccis, Pharaboldis, and, as later revealed, Hetta's own family, as retaliation for the matriarch's disapproval of the sneak coin activities.

pages.blurb: Nakashima was an island located in Kozakura.

geography.paras: Nakashima was located roughly at the midpoint between Tenmei and Shinkoku. The island was infamous for the dangerous reefs that surrounded the coast.

inhabitants.paras: Nakashima was inhabited by fishermen who safely sailed the waters around the island in fishing boats with shallow drafts. They made a profitable living from fishing for abalone, eel and shellfish. They also harvested pearls from oysters. Wako were occasionally seen in the shallow waters around the island.

powers.paras:
By speaking a command word, the wielder of a staff of the adder could cause its head to animate into an adder. This effect lasted for one minute, or until the wielder spoke the command word again to return it to its inanimate form. If the snake was killed while animate, the staff would be destroyed.

If used as a weapon, a staff of the adder could inflict a target with poison.

history.paras:
In the 14th century DR, staves of the adder were often used by clerics of evil deities, giving them ill repute among many.

Sometime in the same century, Reptilla Half-elven lost her hand-crafted staff of the adder in her battle with a bronze dragon whose lair in the Dragonspine Mountains she attempted to claim.

lists: Banak: once the top evil-aligned priest in all the Bloodstone Lands. His staff of the adder was able to fully transform into a serpent and follow the cleric's will.
Fzoul Chembryl: owned a staff of the adder, which he often kept stuck in the umbrella rack in the his tower in Zhentil Keep circa 1357 DR.
Hondrul Meirshin: a priest of the serpent-god Vaerae from Dragonreach who revered snakes, holy to his religion circa 1358 DR.
Quenel: a cleric of Bane and a junior agent of the Zhentarim circa 1358 DR.

Reptilla Half-elven: a talented wizard and a poison-maker who crafted her own staff of the adder in the 14th century DR. Her staff had a unique enchantment allowing it to dispense various types of prisons and venoms. Each had a unique command word.

availability.paras:
Staves of the adder could be found in possession of agents of Zhentarim in Zhentil Keep.

Priests worshiping the god Vaerae, also known as Sseth, carried the staves of the serpent.

Beyond the world of Toril, staves of the adder could be found on the world of Aebrynis and in the Domains of Dread, Nova Vassa and Har'Akir, where the staves were called the staves of Set and wielded by his clerics.

pages.blurb: Accardi was a small coastal village located on the Dragon Coast in interior Faerûn around 1479 DR.

geography.paras: Accardi was located on the shore of the Neck, the strait between the Dragonmere and the Sea of Fallen Stars, and lay opposite Dawngleam in Cormyr. It was connected to the city of Westgate by a trail.

pages.blurb: sphere of annihilation

description.paras: The object was actually a void in the fabric of the multiverse and was utterly black such that no amount of light could penetrate it or reflect off of it. The sphere was 2 ft  (61 cm) in diameter and remained motionless, hovering in position, until acted upon by a mental push from a sentient being.

powers.paras:
The surface of the sphere essentially destroyed whatever it touched. Some described it as being sucked into the void with no chance of resistance or recovery, even by a wish or similar magics. However, the sphere was considered a minor artifact by some and this was evidenced by the immunity that other artifacts seemed to have against being drawn into the void. There were also reports of beings who survived coming in contact with a sphere, but they suffered grievous wounds as if struck by a tremendous force. And finally, divine intervention was a possible path to restoration from annihilation, but getting the attention of a deity to ask a boon was generally fraught with risk.

The sphere was partially responsive to mental commands of movement, with beings of higher intelligence having a better chance of success. The black hole always moved when someone attempted to control it, but not always in the desired direction. A failure was typically indicated by the sphere moving toward the creature that was making the attempt. If two or more people attempted to control the sphere simultaneously, even cooperatively, the chance for success was reduced for all, or it became a contest between the would-be controllers that was largely determined by intelligence and luck.

There was no evidence that a sphere of annihilation had intelligence or awareness, but some adventurers reported that one attacked them when they got too close.

The chances of controlling a sphere of annihilation were greatly improved when in possession of a talisman of the sphere.

The sphere also reacted strangely when it came in contact with portals, gate spells, and other inter-dimensional phenomenon like portable holes. There was a random chance that nothing would happen, the sphere was transported to the destination of the other phenomenon, or every creature and object within 180 ft  (55 m) was whisked off to a random plane of existence. The most likely outcome was that the sphere was simply destroyed, but it was a toss up between that and the other possibilities. Dispel magic and mage's disjunction had no effect on a sphere, but a rod of cancellation that came in contact with a sphere resulted in a blast of mutual destruction that damaged everything within a 60 foot (18 meter) radius.

history.paras: Around 1346 DR, a 10 ft  (3 m) large sphere of annihilation appeared in Luthcheq in Chessenta. To be more precise, it appeared in House Karanok's, the ruling family, torture chamber at the exact place where they were torturing a wizard, completely annihilating that one. The nobles then started to worship the sphere. Around 1370 DR, Tiamat modified the sphere. It started to create smaller ones and to double as a channeling device for the Chromatic Dragon's powers. This allowed her to grant divine spells to the members of House Karanok. These clerics of Tiamat, or Entropy as they called the sphere, also learned to become entropists.

Tristan was a soldier of the Flaming Fist that served Baldur's Gate and its people during the late 15th century DR.

history.paras: Tristan was present at the Waukeen's Rest inn when it was raided and burned down by goblinoid cultists of the Absolute in the Year of Three Ships Sailing, 1492 DR. Trisan became a bit panicked during the disastrous event, but had enough sense to try and rescue those trapped within rather than attempt to douse the out-of-control blaze.

pages.blurb: ring of dragons

description.paras: It was a brass ring that resembled a dragon or serpent biting its own tail.

powers.paras:
The wearer could communicate verbally (such as by tongues) or telepathically (in the manner of Rary's telepathic bond) with any dragon he or she could see. They could also cast a silent image once a day of any dragon he or she had seen with their own eyes.

They could also call to any dracolich or evil dragon by name, although this did not guarantee that the creature would respond or arrive, or be helpful. The dragon or dracolich knew the wearer's location and could use it to locate them. The call continued until the user ended it, removed the ring, or died.

When worn with one of the six amulets of draconic might an individual became immune to the fear effects of dragons and were well-protected from their breath attacks. Furthermore they gained the powerful ability to command dracoliches, as if they were a cleric commanding lesser undead. This power could be used on living, evil-aligned dragons as well, with a chance they could resist its effects. Due to the dangers of attempting to compel a living dragon, this power was seldom used on willful, living dragons.

history.paras: The command powers granted by wearing a ring of dragons in conjunction with an amulet of draconic might was believed to be responsible for the flight of dragons that occurred in the Year of the Worm, 1356 DR.

creation.paras: Forging of a ring of dragons required the spells detect thoughts, sending, silent image, and tongues.

pages.blurb: The Backlands was a region in the Western Heartlands known for its sparse population, wild nature, and many monsters. It was called the Backlands mainly by those that dwelt on the Sword Coast. The central grasslands were known as Pelleor's Prairie.

geography.paras: There were no established borders, but the Backlands were generally described as the lands east of the Serpent's Tail Stream, the Forest of Wyrms, and the Trielta Hills, all the way to the edge of Anauroch. Its southern border was the River Reaching and the northern edge was usually defined as the southern-most Greypeak Mountains. This region included the Greycloak Hills even though some maps placed them at approximately the same latitude as the Greypeaks.

government.paras: This region had no government to speak of. In the 1360s DR, there were tribes of wemics living on the prairie. In the 1370s DR, hunting parties from Najara were known to explore the area.

history.paras: In the days of ancient Netheril, this region was a great source of food from fertile farms.

lists: Drawn Swords, a village between Hill's Edge and the Hill of Lost Souls.
Evereska, a reclusive elven community well-hidden in the Greycloak Hills.
The Halfway Inn, a caravan stop and trading post in the Greycloaks that formed around inn after which it was named.
Ss'thar'tiss'ssun, a ruined temple and city from the Days of Thunder. Briefly inhabited by humans in more modern times as the village of Serpent's Cowl.
The Well of Dragons: a dragon graveyard and holy site for the Cult of the Dragon.
Xonthal's Tower, a thorp that grew around the wizard's tower built on the slopes of Mount Hlim in the Greypeak Mountains.
Yarthrain, a farming village and ruins on the Winding Water.
Blazevale, a wide valley that was only habitable by the hardiest of flora and fauna.[page needed]
The Battle of Bones, site of an ancient battle and subsequently a myriad undead.
Fallen Giant Tomb, an enormous stone carving that honored a great mountain giant chieftain.
The Hill of Lost Souls, a dormant volcano once used as a camp after the Battle of Bones.
The Marsh of Chelimber, an inhospitable marshland. As of 1489 DR it was under the control of Najara.
Skull Gorge, formed by the River Reaching, this is where the last of the goblinoid army met their fate after the Battle of Bones.

Aldanon was a mage in Neverwinter in the 1370s DR.

abilities.paras:
An accomplished wizard, Aldanon had specialized in the art of divination.

In addition, he was capable of crafting magical wands and potions.

history.paras:
Aldanon was a wealthy, yet absent-minded, sage living in Neverwinter. Originally, he built his manse on the outskirts, away from the main thoroughfare, but the reconstruction following the war with Luskan in 1372 DR resulted in his home being in the middle of the new Blacklake district. As such, he began placing wards in order to keep out opportunistic nobles hoping to buy his estate, as well as the murderer on the loose in 1374 DR.

Aldanon had came into the possession of one of the silver shards from the Sword of Gith, though he had long since forgotten who sold it to him. He knew Ammon Jerro from long ago, when he was a court wizard at Castle Never, and knew that Jerro had once possessed a githyanki silver sword (though not that it was Gith's own blade).

When the Kalach-Cha and companions arrived in Neverwinter with a shard, they had Sand examine both that and Duncan's shard, detecting the two had far more power than before. Determining this was beyond his skill, Sand suggested the Kalach-Cha take it to Aldanon for a more professional analysis. Unfortunately, the murders of Dalren and other noblemen led to the Blacklake district being quarantined, forcing the Kalach-Cha to work through the City Watch or Shadow Thieves to get access. After obtaining access, the Kalach-Cha was able to visit Aldanon in his manse. The sage was interested in the two shards, allowing him to compare them to the one he had. After a quick test, he finally determined they were pieces of a githyanki silver sword.

Aldanon knew about the githyanki Sword Stalkers, and that they searched for missing silver swords. He believed that was why they were seeking out the Kalach-Cha and the shards. He knew that Ammon Jerro was more knowledgeable on the subject, but was told he had died long ago, and any research of his would likely be kept in his Haven. He recommended the Kalach-Cha visit the Neverwinter Archives and try to find any information on Jerro, or his family, that could lead to the Haven.

Later, he learned that Lord Tavorick had possession of another silver shard that had been passed around by nobles, and believed that might have been what the Blacklake murderer was trying to find. He sent a message to the Sunken Flagon, but by the time the Kalach-Cha arrived, the house had been taken over by several thugs and Aldanon was missing. Aldanon found himself in Crossroad Keep as a prisoner, and learned from fellow prisoner Zhjaeve that Black Garius had abducted him because of difficulties in deciphering the Tome of Iltkazar. Aldanon remained relatively oblivious of the situation, and became entrenched in the many tomes stored at the keep. Among the rare books Garius and the Arcane Brotherhood had at the keep was a copy of the Tome of Vile Darkness, which Aldanon later noted.

The Kalach-Cha met him again in the (ruined) library after sneaking in through the escape tunnel. Aldanon was still oblivious to Garius's activities, and was far more interested in reading the tomes. The Kalach-Cha commanded him to flee to Neverwinter and warn the city of the possible danger, but not before Aldanon commented that if they started their "dark rituals" the best way to stop them was to make a lot of noise. As the Kalach-Cha stormed the ritual chamber, they lost focus and Garius and his ritualists were destroyed in the shadow backlash. The Greycloaks rescued Zhjaeve from her cell and Lord Nasher granted the keep's control over to the Kalach-Cha.

Back in Neverwinter, at Captain Brelaina's office, Aldanon (confusingly) tried to explain who and what Zhjaeve was to the captain. Brelaina gave up and instead suggested the Kalach-Cha handle it, as the prisoner had specifically requested the Kalach-Cha himself/herself. Aldanon however was anxious to return to the keep and examine the contents of the library there. Once the library was fully refurbished by the Kalach-Cha or Nasher Alagondar, he relocated there for the remainder of the struggle.

Aldanon suspected the shadow tide emerging from the Mere of Dead Men was just an outline, and only strongest at its outer edge. He theorized they could safely strike at the King of Shadows if they could somehow teleport past the shadow barrier and into the heart of Merdelain. He thought the Tome of Iltkazar may have such a means in it, which the Kalach-Cha eventually retrieved from a Shadow Reaver. As the siege of Crossroad Keep raged on, Aldanon searched through the tome. He eventually determined a means to teleport the Kalach-Cha and companions directly into the Vale of Merdelain. With this, the party was able to reach the final dungeon where Black Garius and the King of Shadows were located.

Much later, Aldanon might have reunited with the Kalach-Cha on their wedding ceremony at West Harbor, along with Khelgar Ironfist, Bevil Starling, and Daeghun Farlong.

personality.paras: Aldanon was very absent-minded but easily distracted, never able to stay in one place or examine one thing for very long. He fidgeted constantly, whether cracking his knuckles, tapping his foot, or shuffling about.

Sheaf arrows, also called war arrows,  were arrows that were designed to cause the most physical harm.

description.paras: Far shorter than flight arrows, sheaf arrows measured between 20 inches  (51 centimeters) and 27 inches  (69 centimeters) in length. Sheaf arrows were heavy arrows terminating with sharpened steel tips. These arrows could only be effectively fired with a longbow. Six sheaf arrows could be purchased for 3 silver pieces.

uses.paras: Sheaf arrows were primarily used in warfare.

notable users.paras: Ardasir al-Darah, a janni of the Haunted Lands, carried sheaf arrows.

pages.blurb: The Grey Blossom Regiment was a mercenary company based in Nakamaru in Wa.

description.paras: The company was composed of 500 bushi led by officers who were all no-caste Wanese or natives of Wa.

history.paras: The Grey Blossom Regiment was formed from troops from Shou Lung who defected to Nakamaru's daimyo after the Oni War in 251. In time, they became mostly independent. In 1357 DR, the Regiment operated independently, and only had a samurai liaison officer appointed by the daimyo. For this reason, inside cities they were always watched by an equal numbers of the daimyo's soldiers. Despite this, most clans used Grey Blossom soldiers, including the Funada clan. The Many-Hued Peacock Society and the Royal Vagabonds kept an eye on the Grey Blossom Regiment.

description.paras: Archon was a low-grade fluorspar that was blue to purple and banded with white. Large specimens were used for carving because it was soft and easy to work. A typical price was 2 gp per lb (0.45 kg).

powers.paras: Archon gave off a faint greenish glow if a magically invisible creature or object came within 20 ft (6.1 m). This hardstone was only sensitive to magical invisibility, not creatures on the Ethereal plane or merely in disguise.

Jasper Banff was a priest of Tempus who lived within the deity's temple located in the Cloud Peak Mountains.

history.paras:
When the avatar of Tempus appeared in far-off Battledale during the Time of Troubles in 1358 DR, Jasper and some of his fellow comrades heeded the call of their deity. They left the safety of their home in Amn for the Dalelands far to the east.

When they returned to their temple nearly a decade later, in the Year of the Banner, 1368 DR, they found their brethren were slain and the holy site taken over by Gamaz and other monks of the Order of the Dark Moon. Before he could escape from the worshipers of Shar, Jasper was imprisoned behind a cage that was magically sealed and could only be opened by answering a riddle.

pages.blurb: The Pasocada Basin was a harsh land far north of the rest of Maztica, with which it had very little contact. It was, accordingly, very different both culturally and environmentally.

geography.paras:
The Pasocada Basin was defined as the area drained by the Pasocada River and its tributaries. The mountains surrounding the basin caused a rain shadow and created an arid desert region despite the Basin's temperate temperatures (for instance, the average rainfall was 15 inches per year, but it snowed during winter).

The basin was scattered with mesas and buttes that towered over gullies and canyons. These had been carved by seasonal rains which also deposited great banks of sand. The area was mostly rocky and covered with brush (such as hardy plants like cacti, grasses, and yucca). Rivers and streams flowed through the canyons and gullies, overflowing in flash floods each spring, and wild animals such as coyotes, antelope, bison, and lizards thrived.

The mountains surrounding the basin had much more rainfall, and their slopes were covered in 
coniferous forests (trees such as pine, fir, aspen, and spruce), and were home to such animals as deer, bears, and foxes. Higher in the mountains, above the treeline, the air was much colder and the landscape was perpetually covered in snow. Only yeti and some aarakocra could live here.

The salt flats were areas of the desert where bodies of saltwater had long since evaporated, leaving only the crystalline salt deposits behind. Animals could be found on the edges of a salt flat, but neither plants nor animals lived within (an Earth elemental could occasionally be found, though).

inhabitants.paras:
The Pasocada Basin was home to humans and elves, called Poscadar elves. There were three different human cultures: the agrarian Azuposi, the coastal Metahel, and the nomadic Nahopaca.

In addition, tribes of Dog People and two clans of desert dwarves lived in the nearby regions of the Sands of Itzcala desert.

description.paras: Sathra wore an abundance of black iron jewelry, and she was rather portly in build. An aura of animated, suffering shadows surrounded her.

personality.paras: Sathra was unexpectedly tenacious for a crime lord, craving Angul so badly as to chase its wielder into the Yuirwood.

abilities.paras: In combat, Sathra could call upon the shadows that writhed around her to bring them to bear against many enemies. She was also capable of summoning demons. She also had the power to bring people from the grave as undead. When in combat with Kiril Duskmourn, she employed a number of spells, including one that seemed to temporarily overwhelm Angul's healing powers, possibly graymantle.

possessions.paras: Sathra's office doubled as the Shadow Tongue's treasury. As of 1375 DR, she had recently purchased a torture device known as a "Sembian Cradle".

activities.paras: As the head of the Shadow Tongue, Sathra was involved in a number of crimes, and in plans to corrupt the ruling council of the city.

relationships.paras: Sathra's personal guard was known as the Shadow Cadre. She knew the demon Demoriel by name.

history.paras:
In 1375 DR, the thief Gage broke into the Shadow Tongue lair looking for the enchanted elven sword Angul, which the Shadow Tongue had stolen.Gage says Sathra was after Angul. He found a way into the vault through sheer luck, after Sathra left the door open while leaving. She had been injured by trying to touch the blade herself. She caught the thief not long after, but wielding the blade, he managed to slay many of her bodyguards and even a summoned demon before she retreted.

She pursued Gage and the sword's wielder, Kiril Duskmourn, into the Yuirwood later. The star elf slew her in combat at that time.

rumors & legends.paras:
Sathra was rumoured to have a Red Room in the Shadow Tongue lair where she performed unknown tortures on her victims.

The thief Gage had told some lies to Kiril about Sathra having been hired by a certain Nangulis, per Telarian's indications, to manipulate her into heading for Stardeep. Kiril slew Sathra without first asking about such things.

pages.blurb: The Isle of Gargantuas was one of the Outer Isles of Wa in Kara-Tur, and home to gigantic monsters, called gargantuas.

description.paras: The island was often rent by volcanic eruptions and earthquakes, which devastated the landscape. The air was humid, bearing the stink of sulfur and coal and dense with explosions. Deep granite pits dotted the island, forming traps for the gargantuas.

history.paras:
Around Wa Year 1765 (1347 DR), two krakentua had a titanic battle with more powerful spirits of the ocean. Badly wounded, they escaped to the Isle of Gargantuas to heal and recuperate. One krakentua stayed to rule the island and its monsters by Wa Year 1775 (1357 DR), while the other went to the Fochu Peninsula, seeking humans to worship her.[note 1]

Around Wa Year 1776 (1358 DR), the second krakentua would inflict a vision of a battle on the Isle of Gargantuas on adventurers who visited her at Shinkintin.

inhabitants.paras:
The insectoid and reptilian gargantuas battled each other relentlessly. There were also humanoid gargantuas, who also got in on the action.

They were ruled over by a krakentua, who contented himself with watching their never-ending conflicts and developed a plan to recruit and train an army of gargantuas and attack southern Wa.

wildlife.paras: The rare and prized blue mandarin duck could be found on the Isle of Gargantuas, among other inconveniently hazardous locales.

Jera al-Farif was the owner of Sculptures for the Elite within the Grand Bazaar of Huzuz in 1367 DR.[note 1]

activities.paras:
Jera was one of the most skilled sculpturers in all of Huzuz. Obsidian and marble were his materials of choice, though he used gems to enhances his projects.

If Jera was not completely satisfied with his work at any point during its construction, he would smash the object to bits and begin again.

He charged 500 dinars for a life-sized sculpture, and 100 for smaller ones. His piece depicting the Grand Caliph even adorned the Palace of the Enlightened Throne.

He outright refused to take an order for a piece depicting any kind of genie.

rumors and legends.paras: Unbeknownst to the population of Huzuz, Jera was actually a markeen masquerading as a Zakharan. It was unknown what happened to the original Jera.

description.paras:
These weapons could be found in any dagger form including jambiyas, dirks, stilettos, etc.

Many other weapons in Zakhara could be cursed with the same effect, but daggers were by far the most common.

powers.paras: Using this weapon during combat cursed the wielder with the evil eye. This curse could be removed by a rawun or through the avert evil eye spell but would strike again if the wielder used the dagger again in combat.

pages.blurb: The Church of Savras was a collection of clerics, monks, diviners and specialty priests called sibylites who were devoted to Savras, the All-Seeing One.

organization.paras: The Church of Savras was relatively small as few in Faerûn knew of Savras or held him in poor regard. Savras' clergy was collectively referred to as the divinators. The majority of his clergy was composed of sibylites. Novices were referred to as Truth Seekers. Other titles used in ascending order were Truth Speaker, Savant, Scholar, Sage, Clairvoyant, Soothsayer, Prophesier, Prophet, and Oracle. The highest ranking members of the clergy had unique titles.

activities.paras: All divinators spent a great deal of time meditating in order to gain glimpses of the future.

celebrations.paras: The Vision was celebrated annually during the Feast of the Moon.

base of operations.paras: Savras' largest house of worship was the House of the All-Seeing Orb located in Tashluta. He also maintained a hidden shrine, called the Hall of Pools and Mirrors, deep within Candlekeep.

orders.paras: The Sibylline Sisterhood was an organization of prophetic women who wandered west Faerûn providing prophesies for donations.

The Roar of the Shadows was a titanic conflict between Nobanion, the King of Lions, and his allies against Malar, the Beastlord.

location.paras: This battle occurred within the Gulthmere Forest of the Vilhon Reach.

activities.paras: Honorable Nobanion and a handful of druid allies from the Emerald Enclave clashed with Malar within the Gulthmere Forest during the Time of Troubles in 1358 DR, driving him north and west from the area. Nobanion secured the forest as the seat of his power on Toril, eventually opening a permanent portal to the Beastlands.

Rations were packs of various dry foods that were convenient for extended travels.

description.paras:
Typical rations packed an assortment of jerky, dried fruits, hardtack, and nuts, although several other combinations were possible. Each day's worth of meal was packed in waxed parchment and sackcloth and tied with strings to increase durability, which was at least two weeks.

Ration packs containing hard rolls, dried cheese and fruit, jerky, and tuber vegetables such as potatoes and turnips were available for purchase through Aurora's Whole Realms Catalogue.

reputation.paras: Ration packs produced by the inhabitants of Arvandor were famous for their sweetness.

Court of Proclamations

Basic Information

the second court


Type
Building


Location
Huzuz, Zakhara


Inhabitants of the Court of Proclamations


The Court of Proclamations, or the second court, was part of the complex of the Palace of the Enlightened Throne in Huzuz in 1367 DR.[note 1]

activities.paras:
This large court was capable of holding 2,000 visitors at one time.

Important proclamations were announced here on a weekly basis. The nature of these announcements included awarding new titles, commendations, as well as announcing individuals who had earned disgrace and censure from the court.

history.paras:
Sometime in the late 15th century DR,  Al'chaia led a group of githyanki into the Crystal Labyrinth while tracking down a colony of mind flayers in the Seadeeps level. Upon discovery of the portal leading to Stardock, they converted the abandoned asteroid into a crèche for the breeding and training of young githyanki, which they named Crèche K'liir. The labyrinth was converted into a fortress from where they led attacks against the mind flayers and protected access to Stardock.

Around the Year of Three Ships Sailing, 1492 DR, Al'chaia resided in Stardock.

activities.paras: Al'chaia was in her quarters studying the manual of gainful exercise or the tome of clear thought she had recently found.

relationships.paras: Al'chaia's mount was the loyal Zolcharrx, one of the daughters of Ashtyrranthor, who was her main ally. Her second-in-command Urlon plotted against her.

personality.paras: Al'chaia was very cruel to her subordinates. She knew how to motivate her soldiers, by promising them the two magic books. Al'chaia was worried about the githzerai Ezria her soldiers had recently captured, fearing that more would arrive.

pages.blurb:
The A-Ling Shan mountains.

Gallery
A-Ling Shan

Geography

Type
Mountain range


Region
Yehimal, Hordelands


Elevation
17,000 ft  (5,200 m)–17,000 ft  (5,200 m)


Inhabitants of  A-Ling Shan
Locations in  A-Ling Shan
Organizations in  A-Ling Shan
Settlements  in  A-Ling Shan
Mountains  in  A-Ling Shan


The A-Ling Shan was a mountain range located in the Hordelands.

geography.paras: An extension of the great Yehimal, this mountain range divided the southern portion of Raurin from the Katakoro Plateau. It also marked the northeastern and eastern borders of the kingdom of Ulgarth in the south. The Jumpa River flowed past the A-Ling Shan in the north-west.

description.paras:
Like its parent the Yehimal, the A-Ling Shan was a tangled labyrinth of high, ice-capped peaks. The frozen peaks of this range, most notably the Mahamsaratsu Shan in the east, reached high into the sky. Most reached elevations of between 17,000 ft  (5,200 m) and 17,000 ft  (5,200 m). The A-Ling Shan was among the "high peaks" category of the ranges of the Hordelands, which were typically formed from folded and upthrust granite, with jagged profiles.

Several notable glaciers, including the Shigatse Glacier and the Glacier of the Dragon, were found within the A-Ling Shan range. The glaciers crept at almost the very sides of range. Lakes from glacial run-off formed at the base of the mountains as melting snow and ice were trapped by rocky depressions. Flash flooding was a known danger in the region.

The mountain range was mostly unexplored and unsettled, and only a single pass, Yarlhang La, opened through it in the north, joining the Old Caravan Road. In the west, there were no known points that afforded a crossing of the Jumpa River Gorge below Yarlhang La, so the only passage into the A-Ling Shan was via the eastern valleys.

inhabitants.paras:
Among other terrifying monsters, yetis and dragons were known to make their homes on the cold slopes of the A-Ling Shan, and raided the nearby lands for food. In particular, the Glacier of the Dragon was a major nesting ground for white dragons. Greater oni could also be found in the mountains.

Local fauna included cave bears and snow leopards.

Mahamsaratsu Shan was said to be home to a powerful but evil spirit that lured people to their deaths.

The fortress monastery of the Tiger's Nest stood concealed and inaccessible on the northwestern face of the A-Ling Shan. It was home to the mystical Invisible Tigers monastic order.

pages.blurb: Sending stones

description.paras: Sending stones always came in pairs. They were smooth and delicately carved to match each other, so the pairs were easily recognizable. If one stone from the pair were destroyed, the other would lose its magic.

powers.paras: When activated, a sending stone could be used to cast a sending spell targeted at the bearer of its pair. If the receiving stone had no bearer at the moment of the casting, the stone did not cast the spell and made the user aware of it. This power could be used once, after which the stone regained its magic at dawn.

lists: Beldora, a Harper agent stationed in Bryn Shander in the late 1480s DR, used a sending stone regularly to report to her fellow agent Thwip Ironbottom in Hundelstone.
Salida, a yuan-ti pureblood spy in Port Nyanzaru in the late 1480s or early 1490s DR, used a sending stone to report anyone that was searching for Omu to Ras Nsi.

The Flaming Fist commander Liara Portyr held a sending stone which she used to apprise the Calishite pirate Zaroum Al-Saryak about any ships leaving or entering Port Nyanzaru in the late 1480s or early 1490s DR.

A giant octopus, also known as a cuttlefish (or "cuddlefish"), was a giant-sized breed of octopus found in many oceanic environments. Cuddlefish were the nemeses of ocean-going fishermen and sailors.

description.paras:
Giant octopuses resembled regular octopuses, only much larger, being some 9–12 feet (2.7–3.6 meters) across. Their tentacles alone were at least 10 feet (3 meters) long. These could be studded with barbs and suckers with sharp edges. They were normally colored brown to grey. They had a deep-yellow beak with a bright-orange mouth and tongue.

Hampering descriptions, however, was the fact that giant octopuses had an incredible capacity for camouflage, being able to change their colors and contort and squeeze their bodies to blend in with their environment. They could manifest many different colors and patterns, with green to deep black, red stripes, and blue speckles all known. They typically disguised their tentacles as seaweed. There was only a slight chance of spotting one so disguised, and it was often only the eyes that revealed them.

behavior.paras:
Giant octopuses were aggressive and territorial predators. Though animals, they were considered to be very patient, cunning and even malevolent, but survival was their main focus.

They would freely grab swimmers in the water and even small watercraft to seize and devour their crews. They could stop a craft in its course or even sink it altogether. Sometimes, a crewmember who'd gone missing in the night had fallen prey to a giant octopus, swiftly yanked over the side and consumed without a trace. A wounded or hungry giant octopus switched to scavenging, eating everything it could, down to small crustaceans and seaweed.

They were typically solitary creatures, but would occasionally cooperate in groups of up to three to attack large ships or other food sources.

combat.paras:
A giant octopus had up to eight tentacles to attack with, making it a complex and deadly opponent. Usually, it spared two to anchor itself and attacked with the remaining six. While it could simply strike with the barbed member, it could easily grab hold and then constrict its prey with crushing force. It would also try to drag prey close enough for its savage beak to bite and eat it.

To escape a giant octopus's grasp, it was often vital to attack the tentacles themselves, though it would fight back. If three or four or more tentacles were severed, the wounded giant octopus would most likely try to retreat and hide or return to its lair, and camouflage itself.

abilities.paras:
To cover its escape, the giant octopus could eject a cloud of jet-black ink that utterly obscured the vision of all creatures caught inside. This cloud could be roughly 60 feet wide, 60 feet long, and 20 feet high (18.3 by 18.3 by 6.1 meters) or 20 feet (6.1 meters) in all dimensions. They could do this freely about once a minute.

At the same time, the giant octopus could jet backward in a straight line at up to nearly seven times its normal swimming speed.

Thanks to its camouflage, a giant octopus was skilled at hiding, and its ability to compress its body let it squeeze through many small gaps or escape traps. They were very skilled swimmers.

A giant octopus could regrow severed tentacles, in 2–3 months or in only 11–20 days.

ecology.paras:
Giant octopuses mated in spring. They deposited their eggs in a reef, and left their young to fend for themselves.

Dwelling in warm waters of shallow to medium depth, they made their lairs in underwater caves and even inside shipwrecks. These lairs might hold the inedible remains and treasures of their victims. Giant octopuses preferred to move and hunt at night. Their territories were quite small, and they waited for prey to approach them.

habitats.paras:
Around Faerûn, giant octopuses could be found in the south in the Great Sea and in the Shining Sea, where they lurked in the sunken ruins of Untisczer. Around the Moonshaes, cold-water giant octopuses laired in winding natural sinkholes beneath the pirate cove of Eiresse on the island of Gwynneth.

Around Kara-Tur, giant octopuses could be found in the seas of the east. In Wa, they infested the waters off the coast from the city of Hotomori on the southern side of island of Tsukishima, hindering salvage of a shipwreck around 1357 DR. In Koryo in 1356 DR, a cuddlefish from the deep sea swam into the floating city section of Tu Pe; it killed four men before being captured.

Beyond the Prime Material plane, giant octopuses could be found in the waters of Stygia. Dark giant octopuses could be found lurking in the Shadow Swamp on the Plane of Shadow.

relationships.paras:
Some acted as servants of the marid Kalbari al-Durrat al-Amwaj ibn Jari in her Citadel of Ten Thousand Pearls.

Though very difficult to train, some aquatic rangers were known to have them as animal companions.

usages.paras:
The hide of a giant octopus was tough, leathery, and waterproof. Sailors who by some chance caught and killed one could turn their skin into fine ponchos to keep the rain off.

However, giant octopuses were most often hunted for their ink. It could be used to scribe magical scrolls.

A piece of a giant octopus tentacle was one of the material components of the battle tentacles spell.

In the Blade Kingdoms, cuttlefish was considered a sizable, but somewhat disappointing feast centerpiece dish.

lists: Slulushtup, an awakened giant octopus druid of Deep Sashelas.

Aloxag

Basic Information

Home
Undermountain


Race
Spectator



Dates

1370 DR  Slain while defending Ibbalar Thrul



Aloxag was the trusted bodyguard spectator who served Ibbalar Thrul in his Undermountain lair in the mid–14th century DR.

history.paras: In the Year of the Tankard, 1370 DR, Ibbalar Thrul constructed a magical apparatus that was powered by a rare enchanted Kossuth ruby. Using the magical portal pool, Ibbalar called forth a small army of spectators and sent them into Waterdeep to "guard" powerful magical items, such as Piergeiron the Paladinson's enchanted sword. The floating aberrations created chaos in the city, and Khelben Arunsun sent his trusted agent into the mega-dungeon underneath the Yawning Portal to find and stop the nuisance invasion. That Khelbenite managed to infiltrate the mad wizard's lair and confronted what he thought to be Ibbalar Thrul himself. In reality, Aloxag took the wizard's place, allowing him to escape the punishment from the Lords of Waterdeep. Aloxag was slain in the process.

pages.blurb: riqq

description.paras: Riqqs were essentially tiny drum fixed with chimes or bells into slots around the sides.

history.paras: Riqqs were often used by dancers to keep tempo during a performance. Smaller version of riqqs called daffs were used by the natives of the Furrowed Mountains.
The family held partial financial ownership of the Flaming Fist mercenary company. At one point however, they were forced to sell their interest to help pay significant debts they had incurred.

Whistling Wizard

Basic Information

Aliases

Type

# of floors

Location

Owner(s)
Harauna Beltzund


Staff

Quality
Fair


Price
